description: From Middle English maligne, from Old French maligne, from Latin malignus, from malus (“bad”) + genus (“sort, kind”). Compare benign.

adjectives.description: malign (comparative more malign, superlative most malign)

entries.meaning: Evil or malignant in disposition, nature, intent or influence.

examples: He was sure they [the stars] were arranged in some order which had a secret and malign significance.

verbs.description: malign (third-person singular simple present maligns, present participle maligning, simple past and past participle maligned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make defamatory statements about; to slander or traduce.
(transitive, archaic) To treat with malice; to show hatred toward; to abuse; to wrong.
examples: The people practice what mischiefs and villainies they will against private men, whom they malign by stealing their goods, or murdering them.
